Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: AGNES: Algebraic Geometry NorthEastern Series
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation in six AGNES (Algebraic Geometry Northeastern Series) conferences which will be held at Stony Brook University on April 21-23, 2017, at Northeastern University in Fall 2017, at Rutgers University in Spring 2018, at Brown University in Fall 2018, at University of Massachusetts Amherst in Spring 2019, and at Boston College in Fall 2019. AGNES is a semi-annual algebraic geometry meeting organized at a rotating location by an association of northeastern universities. A guiding goal of AGNES is to introduce graduate students to a broad spectrum of current research in algebraic geometry. While meeting this goal, AGNES has become an important center for algebraic geometry in the US. The conference has an extensive record of promoting collaboration and has developed new tools for training and mentoring future leaders in algebraic geometry. These consist of graduate mini-schools, career panels, poster presentations for junior participants (including undergraduate students), and events specifically targeting members of groups that are under-represented in the mathematical sciences.

Algebraic geometry is a sub-field of mathematical sciences that studies solution sets of polynomial equations. It has deep connections to many other areas of pure mathematics, such as topology, arithmetic, number theory, differential geometry, dynamical systems, and homological algebra. At the same time algebraic geometry has found important applications in applied mathematics and computer science (computer vision, geometric complexity theory, numerical methods in algebraic statistics, etc). The centerpiece research activity of each AGNES meeting will be 7-8 invited lectures given by speakers showcasing different facets of algebraic geometry. The scientific scope of AGNES will be further expanded by lectures from neighboring mathematical subjects (such as arithmetic geometry, dynamics, complex geometry, and computational geometry) and by the various supporting activities described above. Further information can be found at the conference website: http://www.agneshome.org/

POR.DRECONTENT:
AGNES (which stands for Algebraic Geometry Northeastern Series) is a series of algebraic geometry conferences, organized twice a year by several universities in the northeastern United States, on a rotating basis. The AGNES conferences bring together algebraic geometers, other mathematicians, and even some non-mathematicians (such as physicists) for a series of weekend lectures on cutting-edge results in mathematics. There are also "pre-lectures" that explain some of the background material to younger mathematicians, who form the majority of the audience. Almost every meeting also features a professional development event for discussing important aspects of the profession beyond math research, or a poster session allowing younger participants to present their work - often their PhD dissertations. The workshops are well-attended, primarily by mathematicians from the Northeast (the target audience), but also by many mathematicians from all over the United States, and even some from abroad. The organizers also collect feedback from participants, and make adjustments accordingly, in order to make the workshops as useful as possible.

The Spring 2017 workshop at Stony Brook University was a large meeting, with 144 registered participants. The lectures were recorded and are freely available from the AGNES webpage.  In this way, the workshop reaches an even larger group of mathematicians.

There were eight research lectures during the weekend, including two by female mathematicians and one by a junior mathematician. There were three pre-lectures for younger mathematicians. On the Friday before the main workshop, there was a mini-school, with lectures given by Mihai Paun, one of the leading experts in the field of complex algebraic and analytic geometry, and local experts. The mini-school had 87 registered participants. The professional development event was a discussion about publishing in mathematics, led by Jonathan Wahl, Olivier Debarre, and Robert Lazarsfeld, all of whom have extensive experience as editors of prestigious mathematics journals. There were many informal discussions among the participants during the breaks between lectures.  

The anonymous feedback from participants was very positive.  Participants commented on the nice variety of speakers and topics, on the great opportunity to meet new people and to learn about new research directions; junior participants, as always, greatly appreciated the pre-talks. Participants also stressed the continuing value of a regular series of events like AGNES for keeping abreast of research developments, and meeting colleagues face-to-face to share ideas and solve problems.
